Posts.Content: scary wrote: I know I have a dog ear in the front, but I don't know what the thing at the back of my arm is.  but it's near where the drain was after the lymph node biopsy during the mastectomy.  almost 3 weeks out, and it still hurts so much to sleep on my right side.  but, it's soft, so i wonder if they can drain some fluid out of it?  i have another post-op appt. tomorrow, but i am really curious about this. Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2014 03:35PM scary wrote: Well, it looks like it may be used for recon. because Medicaid won't let me get the left one removed.  So that extra boob will become a small right boob, with the left one reduced to match, which medicaid will approve.  yeah, that thing is a pain in the butt, to say the least.

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2014 11:49AM scary wrote: well, the dr. said it's just the side skin, and it's not fluid, it's just me (ick), which the plastic surgeon can fix later.

Posts.Content: scary wrote: I posted this in another forum, but it may have been seen as off-topic, so i will ask here. I have a question about follow-up care for my other gynecological parts (ovaries, etc.)  I don't have a regular gynecologist right now.  I go to a sliding scale clinic that did my women's exams and sent me for the mammogram through the best chance network, and now I am on Medicaid.  Is it normal protocol to get my ovaries checked now?   The clinic I went to did the basic pap smear, etc., which was normal, but they said they don't do the uterus, ovaries, etc.  Do I need to get myself a regular gynecologist now that I'm covered?  Do most women who have breast cancer get their ovaries checked too? Dx 2/17/2014, IDC, Right, 1cm, Stage IA, Grade 2, 0/14 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 2/17/2014, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/14 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 3/6/2014 Mastectomy: Right Hormonal Therapy 4/17/2014 Femara (letrozole) Surgery 6/25/2014 Reconstruction (right): Tissue expander placement Surgery 10/29/2014 Reconstruction (right) Surgery 5/18/2015 Reconstruction (right): Silicone implant Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: question about ovaries in relation to breast cancer scary scary

Posts.Content: May 6, 2014 09:27PM scary wrote: thank you all for the answers.  i am going to my pcp next week and asked that i get fsh and prolactin taken.  I have a history of prolactinoma, and want to make absolutely certain that i am in menopause even though i have been without a period of two years, because there could be other problems that are causing the lack of periods.  if the fsh shows i am not yet in menopause, the femara (which i like and want to stay on) would not be effective.  i will find myself an ob-gyn to ask about getting my ovaries checked.
Posts.Title: question about ovaries in relation to breast cancer scary scary
Would you mind sharing your age at time of diagnosis? ByFaith Gussy

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2014 07:49PM scary wrote: I am a stage one, grade 2, so i guess i belong here.  I will know in a week or two whether i need chemo, depending on the oncotype results, or just hormone treatments, since i'm estrogen and progesterone positive.  hugs to my sisters.
